stream_context.summary: Kaze tests Course 7’s new ambient SFX, fixes long-standing audio crackling, juggles RAM and precision issues while polishing the giant overworld and planning the flying-ship/wing-cap areas.

development_findings.summary: Added bespoke ambient sounds (elevator, fire, roller-coaster, Shy Guy) to Course 7 to make the carnival section feel alive.
development_findings.quote: Just adding a couple sound effects makes it... I love this.

development_findings.summary: Eliminated a persistent audio crackling bug that affected the whole project.
development_findings.quote: I made the most important fix in history yesterday. The audio crackling is gone.

development_findings.summary: Adopted a new UV-mapping tool that speeds up making geometry look decent.
development_findings.quote: Man, this new UV mapping tool is great.

development_findings.summary: Overworld design now includes a flying-ship shipyard; a baby Yoshi will jump on Mario and trigger a cut-scene once the player has enough stars.
development_findings.quote: When you have enough stars, you jump on and the cut-scene starts and flies off.

development_findings.summary: Wing-cap level still unimplemented; current plan is to place it above the Koopa-with-Cough area, accessible through the hotel room.
development_findings.quote: Where the fuck is the wing cap? ... Oh—the hotel room. Right. That makes sense.

development_findings.summary: Removed unused actors (comet, UFO platform) and re-exported without certain features to free RAM in a level that was crashing.
development_findings.quote: We’re out of memory in this level so let me just make up some memory by killing unused assets.

development_findings.summary: Project uses the full 8 MB N64 RAM by default to simplify programming despite occasional memory pressure.
development_findings.quote: Well, we’re using the whole 8 MB, just because that saves some time… if we have 8 MB anyway, we might as well use all 8.

development_findings.summary: Shifted to a newer build of Project64 for testing and identified at least one crash as a RAM issue rather than emulator bug.
development_findings.quote: Hey, it was a RAM issue. I need to fix this for Sauraen.

development_findings.summary: Upgrading to Sauraen’s custom F3DX3 microcode increased fixed-point precision roughly eight-fold, reducing visual artifacts at no performance cost.
development_findings.quote: That has increased the precision eightfold… without any cost.

development_findings.summary: Fifteen courses are complete; only three overworld sectors remain in first art pass, positioning the project at the final stretch.
development_findings.quote: We finished 15 courses now and now we’re just finishing the overworld—so we are like the final stretch.

development_findings.summary: Game already contains 100+ custom songs and runs on real N64 hardware at up to four times the original game’s size.
development_findings.quote: It is a gigantic game—probably four times the size of the original—and it all runs on real hardware.

development_findings.summary: Main schedule drag comes from sophisticated character interactions and extra custom code, far beyond the initial vision of a quick 50-level hack.
development_findings.quote: The main reason this hack is taking long is because we have like character interactions and stuff.

development_findings.summary: Started blocking out melon-farming fields; complex UV mapping anticipated.
development_findings.quote: This is going to be such a pain to UV-map. Oh fuck.

context_findings.summary: Kaze’s philosophy: game development equals suffering, yet preferable to passive content consumption.
context_findings.quote: Developing video games is suffering. The Buddhists had it right—life is suffering.

context_findings.summary: Moved to Canada in 2021; lives with wife Zeina and their baby; balances streams with family life.
context_findings.quote: Yep, I live here with my wife and a little baby actually.

context_findings.summary: Works remotely for Gears for Breakfast on undisclosed commercial project; NDA limits what he can reveal.
context_findings.quote: My real job is… a game programmer job, and I can’t tell you what I’m making without breaking NDA.

context_findings.summary: Streams five times a week for roughly seven hours each, indicating heavy personal time investment.
context_findings.quote: I have new Unreal Engine. Five times a week. For around seven hours at a time.

context_findings.summary: Expressed fear of being compared to Jordan Peterson for habitually clarifying questions.
context_findings.quote: My biggest fear is that people are going to accuse me of talking like Jordan Peterson…

biobak.summary: Updated pirate-ship sail texture to look rougher and more pirate-like.
biobak.quote: I’m not sure if Biobak completely replaced the sail texture or if he just put holes into it, but this looks a lot more pirate-y now.

zeina.summary: Provides real-time feedback; reacted positively to new overworld shortcut piece.

key_stories.title: Killing the Crackle
key_stories.summary: A persistent audio crackle had haunted the project for months. Kaze finally traced and removed the root cause, celebrating on-stream.
key_stories.challenge: Annoying audio distortion across the entire game.
key_stories.process: Investigated sample handling and audio pipeline, pushed fixes the previous day.
key_stories.outcome: Crackling eliminated; morale boost for the team and better player experience.
key_stories.key_quote: The audio crackling is gone—can you believe it?

key_stories.title: Precision Upgrade
key_stories.summary: Depth and vertex precision issues caused flickering and artifacts. Collaborating with Sauraen, Kaze adopted a custom F3DX3 microcode that multiplies precision without extra cost.
key_stories.challenge: Limited fixed-point precision in Nintendo’s original microcode caused rendering glitches.
key_stories.process: Sauraen rewrote parts of the microcode; Kaze ported the project to it and tested on hardware.
key_stories.outcome: Visual stability greatly improved; N64 performance unchanged.
key_stories.key_quote: Nintendo had a weird operation that lost a lot of precision… now the precision issue is much smaller in my game.

key_stories.title: The Flying Shipyard
key_stories.summary: Designing the overworld’s shipyard that transforms into a flying ship once enough stars are collected.
key_stories.challenge: Create an engaging progression gate and cinematic payoff.
key_stories.process: Mapped out location, planned baby Yoshi trigger, evaluated size and placement to avoid empty space.
key_stories.outcome: Concept locked; implementation pending, with further design on the ship model and cut-scene.
key_stories.key_quote: Once you have enough star power, it flies off.

key_stories.title: Overworld Memory Crunch
key_stories.summary: A critical level kept crashing due to memory exhaustion.
key_stories.challenge: 8 MB RAM limit and wasteful assets in a large overworld area.
key_stories.process: Removed unused comet and UFO actors, re-exported level without Bleed-In-Line, and switched to a newer emulator build for testing.
key_stories.outcome: Crash resolved; free RAM reclaimed for future content.
key_stories.key_quote: Let me just make up some memory by killing unused assets.

open_questions.context: Kaze says precision is eight-times higher with no cost but didn’t explain the technical rewrite.
questions: What specific changes were made in F3DX3 to gain eight-fold precision?
How did you validate it on real hardware?
Were there any trade-offs or features you had to drop?

open_questions.context: High-level concept shared, but no model, mechanics, or cut-scene details exist yet.
questions: What gameplay role will the flying ship serve beyond transport?
How will the wing-cap level tie into the shipyard narrative?
What visual style and mechanics are planned for the cut-scene?

open_questions.context: Kaze removes assets ad-hoc and uses full 8 MB; long-term plan unclear.
questions: Do you have formal RAM budgets per level?
What tooling helps you detect over-allocation early?
How do you balance ambition with hardware limits?

open_questions.context: Kaze claims interactions are the main delay.
questions: Which character systems are most time-consuming?
Can you share an example of a particularly tricky interaction?
How do these systems push SM64’s original engine?

open_questions.context: 100+ tracks exist but Badub was not mentioned in this stream.
questions: What is Badub’s workflow for composing N64-ready music?
How much of the OST is final versus placeholder?
Any technical hurdles converting modern compositions to N64 format?

open_questions.context: Stream shows real-time tweaks but doesn’t cover collaborative pipelines.
questions: How do Biobak, Zeina, and Badub deliver assets to you?
What version-control or asset-tracking tools keep the project organized?
How do time-zones and family life affect meetings and feedback loops?
